variant.figure: Christa Hauenschild Susanne Heizmann (Editors) Machine Translation and Translation Theory
variant.figureCaption: This volume contains papers presented at the 2nd International Workshop "Machine Translation and Translation Theory" held at the University of Hildesheim in 1994, as well as invited contributions. Experts from Europe and the United States demonstrate how machine translation can profit from insights gained in translation theory and vice versa.

variant.note: The Language of Cambridge... Corpus Linguistics Investigating Language Structure and Use
variant.author: Douglas Biber, Susan Conrad, and Rand! Reppen
variant.bodyText: This book is about investigating the way people use language in speech and writing. It introduces the corpus-based approach to the study of lan- guage, based on analysis of large databases of real language examples and illustrates exciting new findings about language and the different ways that people speak and write. The book is important both for its step-by-step descriptions of research methods and for its findings about grammar and vocabulary, language use, language learning, and differences in language use across texts and user groups.
variant.figure: Cambridge Approaches to Linguistics 0-521-49622-5 Hardback $59.95 0-521-49957-7 Paperback $19.95
variant.subsectionHeader: Their Names, Forms and Powers John Coleman
variant.bodyText: This book reviews current theories of the sound- structure of words and syllables. Dr. Coleman presents technical arguments showing that the contemporary theories are too complex and that a simpler theory, Declarative Phonology, is adequate. This theory is exemplified with detailed accounts of the sound-structure of words and syllables in English and Japanese.
variant.figure: Cambridge Studies in Linguistics 85 0-521-47208-3 Hardback $74.95 Japanese/Korean Linguistics Volume 7
variant.construct: Noriko Akatsuka, Hajime Hoji, Shoichi Iwasaki, and Susan Strauss, Editors Contributors: Sen/so Maynard Hiroko Furo, Mutsuko Endo Hudson, Makoto Hayashi, Junko Nori, Tsuyoshi Ono, En Yoshida, Mieko Banno, Naomi McGloin, Scott Saft, Shigeko Okamoto, Susan Strauss, Yong-Yae Park, Rodney Tyson, Peter Hendriks, Katsunobu kunst, Akio Kamio, Yoshiko Matsumoto, Yasuhiro Shirai, Satoshi Uehara, Dat/so Chung, Yuki Hi rose, Soon At Chun, Hisako Ikawa, Young-chul Jun. Soo won Kim, Joan Maling, I6yomi Kusumoto, Gunsoo Lee, Nanako Machida, Keiko Miyagawa, William McClure, Kunio Nishiyama, Fun Cho, Hiromu Sakai, Peter Sells, Satoshi Tomioka, Shin Watanabe, Hae-Kyung Wee, Sachiko Ohno, Sechang Lee, Seung-Hoon Shin, Jennifer L Smith, Motoko Ueyama, Sun-Ah Jun, Satoshi I6nsui, Hajime Hoji
variant.subsectionHeader: Japanese/Korean Linguistics Distributed for CSLI Publications Dynamic Conceptual Semantics
variant.sectionHeader: A Data-oriented Theory of Concept Formation and Understanding
variant.bodyText: Presented in this book is a theory of concept formation and understanding that does not make use of a notion of an innate mental language as a means of concept representation. Instead, experimental concepts are treated semantically as stabilizing structuring of growing sets of data, which are sets of experienced satisfaction situa- tions for expressions, and theoretical concepts are based on coherent sets of general sentences held true.
variant.subsectionHeader: Studies in Logic, Language and Information Distributed for CSLI Publications
What Comes First in Dynamic Semantics
variant.bodyText: A Critical Review of Linguistic Theories of Presupposition and a Dynamic Alternative

Inspired by Frege, who's work in Linguistic Presupposition initiated the modern study, Beaver shares with the reader the most comprehensive overview and critical discussion of this burgeon- ing field published to date. He then goes on to motivate and develop his own account based on a Dynamic Semantics in which the Tarskian emphasis on truth conditions is questioned. Studies in Logic, Language and Information Distributed for CSLI Publications

Lecture Notes 8/ Distributed for CSLI Publications 1-57586-101-1 Hardback $59.95 1-57586-100-3 Paperback $22.95
variant.bodyText: This introduction is concerned with the semantics of natural languages. The text examines what issues semantics, as a theory of meaning, should address; determining what the meanings of words of the language are and how to semantically com- bine elements of a language to build up complex meanings.

variant.subsectionHeader: Constructive Case Evidence From Australian Languages Rachel Nordlinger
variant.bodyText: Australian Aboriginal languages have many inter- esting grammatical characteristics that challenge some of the central assumptions of current lin- guistic theory. This volume focuses on the complex properties of case morphology in these noncon- figurational languages, including extensive case stacking and the use of case to mark tense/aspect/ mood.
variant.figure: Dissertations in Linguistics Distributed for CSLI Publications 1-57586-135-6 Hardback $64.95 1-57586-134-8 Paperback $23.95
variant.subsectionHeader: Semantic Incorporation and Indefinite Descriptions Semantic and Syntactic Aspects of Noun Incorporation in West Greenlandic Veerle Van Geenhoven
variant.bodyText: This volume presents "Semantic Incorporation" as an analysis accounting for many striking similarities between the semantic properties of incorporated nouns in West Greenlandic and bare plurals and split noun phrases in West Germanic language.
variant.table: Dissertations in Linguistics Distributed for CSLI Publications 1-57586-133-X Hardback $69.95 1-57586-132-1 Paperback $27.95
variant.subsectionHeader: Parsing Below the Segment in a Constraint-Based Framework Cheryl Zoll
variant.bodyText: This book proposes a new way of understanding the behavior of consonants and vowels in a broad cross-section of the world's languages. A new model of subsegmental phonology within Optimality Theory that differs from standard Autosegmental Phonology both in its limited use of representa- tional distinctions and in the form of the grammar to which the representations submit is introduced.

variant.bodyText: Communication is power. An idea, passed from person to person, and village to village, can transform the world. Start with the right idea.

variant.bodyText: LLBA's timely and comprehensive coverage speaks volumes on current ideas in linguistics and language research. Available in print, online, on CD-ROM (from SilverPlatter and NISC) and on magnetic tape. Visit our Web site: www.socabs.org for product information, links to relevant sites, and subscription-based access to the LLBA Speech, Language and Hearing Pathology subset.
variant.figure: Lua Linguistics and Language Behavior Abstracts P.O. Box 22206, San Diego, CA 92192-0206 619/695-8803 • Fax: 619/695-0416 • email: socio@cerfnet.com Linguistics and Philosophy MI/ Editor-in-Chief: Manfred Krifka
variant.affiliation: Dept. of Linguistics, University of Texas at Austin, USA
variant.bodyText: Linguistics and Philosophy is a journal for studies focused on natural language, and is of interest to practitioners in the disciplines covered in the title. Although the field thus described is so extensive that a complete listing of relevant topics is precluded, at least the following specifically fall within it: - traditional areas in the philosophy of language such as meaning, truth, reference, description, entailment, speech acts - traditional areas of linguistics such as syntax, semantics and pragmatics (when the studies are of sufficient explicitness and generality to be also of philosophical interest) - aspects of artificial intelligence concerned with language such as computational linguistics and natural language processing - systems of logic with strong connections to natural language: modal logic, tense logic, epistemic logic, intensional logic - philosophical questions raised by linguistics as a science: linguistics methodology, the status of linguistics theories, the nature of linguistic universals - philosophically interesting problems at the intersection of linguistics and other disciplines: language acquisition, language and perception, language as a social convention.

variant.bodyText: (December 1997. Kathleen McKeowrL ACL Secretary/Treasurer) (list in PAYMENT SECTION)

Manuscripts for Computational Linguistics should be submitted on letter-size paper (8.5 by 11 inches, or A4), double-spaced and single-sided throughout, including footnotes and refer- ences. The paper should begin with an informative abstract of approximately 150-250 words. Manuscripts must be written in English. Contact the editor regarding the possibility of electronic submission.
variant.subsectionHeader: Submissions may be made in any of the following categories: ,
variant.bodyText: Papers: This category includes contributions that report significant new research results in com- putational linguistics or that provide critical reviews of the literature on a particular topic. The length of a paper depends on its content, but it is suggested that manuscripts be limited to forty double-spaced, pages. That is the equivalent of thirty journal pages. Each paper is fully refereed by three or four experts in the field. Manuscripts may also be submitted electronically; consult http:/ /www.cs.columbia.edu/—radev/acl/subrnit.txt for instructions and pointers to the LATEX style files. The submission of ah article to CL for refereeing means that the author certifies the manuscript is not Copyrighted; nor has it been published or submitted for publica- tion to another refereed journal. If any version of the paper has appeared, or will appear, in a non-refereed publication, the details of such publication must be made known to the Editor at the time of submission. The final version of a paper tentatively accepted for publication must be accompanied by a Copyright Transfer Agreement signed by all of the authors or, in the case of a "work for hire," by the employer. This written transfer is necessary under the 1978 U.S. Copyright law. Letters to the Editor: This category includes statements of opinion on- issues relevant to the readership. The Editor and the editorial board will evaluate the appropriateness of these con- tributions for inclusion. Five copies of papers or three copies of letters should be sent to:
variant.table: Julia Hirschberg, CL Editor AT&T Labs-Research 180 Park Avenue, A237 Florham Park, NJ 07932-0971 (+1 973) 360-8330; acl@research.att.com Squibs and Discussions: This category includes short articles reporting technical results, dis- cussions of results, algorithms, or new computational linguistic data or tools of interest to the journal readership. Submission format is the same as for regular papers, but the length should in no case exceed eight journal pages. Electronic submissions (LATEX source, postscript or plain text) are welcome and should be submitted to: Pierre Isabelle, CL Squibs and Discussions Editor RALI, DIRO Universite de Montreal C. P. 6128, Succ. Centre-ville Montreal, Quebec, CANADA H3C 3J7 (+1 514) 343-6161; isabelle@iro.umoritreal.ca Book Section: Anyone interested in reviewing a book, or in suggesting a book for review, should contact the Book Review Editor; publishers may also submit copies of books for review directly to: Graeme Hirst, CL Book Review Editor University of Toronto Department -of Computer Science Toronto, CANADA M5S 3G4 (+1 416) 978-8747; gh@cs.toronto.edu
variant.bodyText: Founded in 1962, the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) is the primary scientific and professional society for natural language processing research and applications. A European chapter was established in 1982. Besides publishing Computational Linguistics, the ACL holds international meetings (annually in North America, biennially in Europe) where the state-of-the-art in natural language processing research and development is presented. Recently, special interest groups on the Mathematics of Language, the Lexicon, Parsing, Generation, Computational Phonology, Multimedia Language Processing, and Very Large Corpora have been formed; others are likely to be added.

Rand Reppen
variant.abstract: This book is about investigating the way people use language in speech and writing. It introduces the corpus-based approach to the study of language, based on analysis of large databases of real language examples and illustrates exciting new findings about language and the different ways that people speak and write. The book is important both for its step-by-step descriptions of research methods and for its findings about grammar and vocabulary, language use, language learning, and in language texts and user groups.
variant.title: Phonological Representations Their Names, Forms and Powers
variant.author: John Coleman
variant.abstract: This book reviews current theories of the soundstructure of words and syllables. Dr. Coleman presents technical arguments showing that the contemporary theories are too complex and that a simpler theory, Declarative Phonology, is adequate. This theory is exemplified with detailed accounts of the sound-structure of words and syllables in English and Japanese.
variant.author: Noriko Akatsuka
Hajime Hoji
variant.address: Strauss, Maynard Hiroko Furo, Mutsuko Endo Hudson, Makoto Hayashi, Junko Nori, Tsuyoshi Ono, En Yoshida, Mieko Banno, Naomi McGloin, Scott
variant.degree: Saft, Shigeko Okamoto, Susan Strauss, Yong-Yae Park, Rodney Tyson, Peter Hendriks, Katsunobu kunst, Akio Kamio, Yoshiko Matsumoto, Yasuhiro Shirai, Satoshi Uehara, Dat/so Chung, Yuki Hi rose, Soon At Chun, Hisako Ikawa, Young-chul Jun. Soo won Kim, Joan Maling, I6yomi Kusumoto, Gunsoo Lee, Nanako Machida, Keiko Miyagawa, William McClure, Kunio Nishiyama, Fun Cho, Hiromu Sakai, Peter Sells, Satoshi Tomioka, Shin Watanabe, Hae-Kyung Wee, Sachiko Ohno, Sechang Lee,
variant.title: Seung-Hoon Shin, Jennifer L Smith, Motoko Ueyama, Satoshi I6nsui, Hajime Hoji Japanese/Korean Linguistics Distributed for CSLI Publications Dynamic Conceptual Semantics A Data-oriented Theory of Concept Formation and Understanding
variant.author: Renate Bartsch
variant.abstract: Presented in this book is a theory of concept formation and understanding that does not make a notion of an innate mental language as a means of concept representation. Instead, experimental concepts are treated semantically as stabilizing structuring of growing sets of data, which are sets of experienced satisfaction situations for expressions, and theoretical concepts are based on coherent sets of general sentences held true.
variant.note: Studies in Logic, Language and Information Distributed for CSLI Publications 1-57586-125-9 Hardback about 1-57586-124-0 Paperback $24.95
variant.title: What Comes First in Dynamic Semantics A Critical Review of Linguistic Theories of Presupposition and a Dynamic Alternative
variant.author: David Beaver
variant.abstract: Inspired by Frege, who's work in Linguistic Presupposition initiated the modern study, Beaver shares with the reader the most comprehensive overview and critical discussion of this burgeoning field published to date. He then goes on to motivate and develop his own account based on a Dynamic Semantics in which the Tarskian emphasis on truth conditions is questioned.
variant.note: Studies in Logic, Language and Information Distributed for CSLI Publications 1-57586-121-6 Hardback 1-57586-120-8 Paperback $24.95
